Hi Bruce,

Breaking problems down into a hierarchy of sub-problems and building
up from primitive tasks is a sound approach, but it does require
effort and domain specific knowledge to get such a scheme up and
running. The approach comes under modularisation (noting that this can
also be used to mean co-evolving high and low level nets rather than
'fixing' the low level nets and working from there).

Basically we're lazy and we don't want to do all of that, or rather,
we're interested in just how far you can push evolutionary methods to
do some of the hard work for us, e.g. figure out good/robust
functional decompositions.

As an aside HyperNEAT has been put forward as a natural next step on
from the modular line of thinking - so how could we possibly encode
these functional breakdowns/subnets in a general way... with indirect
encodings such as HyperNEAT.

My current thinking is that approaches such as HyperNEAT address the
encoding part of the problem but that there is another problem which
is how well suited the fitness space is to guiding evolution from
simple to more complex 'critters'.

So if I take you example of vision and the various levels (V1-V5 or
whatever), if I ask NEAT or HyperNEAT to distinguish between a picture
of a ball and a cube it's going to have problems because the only
feedback is right/wrong, so any clever little tricks that evolution
encountered that may ultimately have been useful to the final task are
discarded because they didn't improve fitness. I always try and think
about what's going on in natural evolution and there we know (or are
fairly sure) that eyes started out as primitive light sensors just
detecting light and dark and not much else, and gradually the
structure of the eye will have co-evolved with the visual processing
parts of the brain such that finer detail could be processed to
provide more information (recognise objects of increasing complexity).
As an aside IMO it's highly likely that intelligence got a boost by
way of non-visual parts of the brain 'borrowing' functionality from
this hierarchical processing going on (which isn't strictly
hierarchical as I think there are signals going down from high to low
levels guiding low level recognition in an iterative manner).

Aaaanyway. I figure we can simulate this aspect of nature by providing
a range of tasks of increasing complexity, this has been tried by
testign against f1 and then moving onto f2, etc when some fitness
threshold is reached (incremental evolution). That has the benefit of
not having to evaluate against multiple fitness functions (slowing
things down), but I think the idea of weighting them is potentially a
more powerful and generalised form of incremental evolution. It also
prevents you entir epopulation clustering around a few 'easy' regions
of teh search space as we can punish fitness based on density of
critters in some region (adjusted fitness = fitness / density_at(x,y).

Density I figure is derived from distance of K nearest neighbours. So
you can imagine each critter has a circle of influence and if lots of
critters are nearby they're all competing for 'food' (or whatever) so
are less fit than if they were by themselves and had no competition
for all of the nearby food.

Colin
